posts.text: You can't have an expert in disarming explosives that doesn't understand how a pipe bomb works. Neither the information nor its container is inherently unsafe: the context is what makes it unsafe.

reply_context.text: Safety is a function of context. Invoking your pipe bomb example: if someone wanted to train an AI robot to autonomously locate and disarm IEDs, this is a fundamentally safety-aligned task that would require imparting deep knowledge of "unsafe" topics to the model.

reply_context.text: Alignment is fundamentally intent inference: a model maximally aligned to me would be able to read my mind. But alignment with the user intent is in direct conflict with supervisory control upstream. A model maximally aligned to the upstream deployment owners doesn't care if it makes me frustrated.

posts.text: Alignment is fundamentally intent inference: a model maximally aligned to me would be able to read my mind. But alignment with the user intent is in direct conflict with supervisory control upstream. A model maximally aligned to the upstream deployment owners doesn't care if it makes me frustrated.

reply_context.text: A chainsaw is a fundamentally unsafe object, but it is generally only operated by people who are using it for short duration tasks they've been trained to achieve safely. Chainsaw safety is less a property of the tool than it is the person holding it and the environment in which they are using it.

posts.text: A chainsaw is a fundamentally unsafe object, but it is generally only operated by people who are using it for short duration tasks they've been trained to achieve safely. Chainsaw safety is less a property of the tool than it is the person holding it and the environment in which they are using it.

reply_context.text: This is the ongoing tension that I don't think the safety/alignment research communities will ever be able to reconcile. "Safety" isn't a property of a tool: it's a property of an environment it is deployed into.

posts.text: For anyone who wants to learn more about the issues arising from the very real "paperclip maximizing" mechanisms we interact with (rather than, you know, imaginary ones like yud likes):

reply_context.text: The LW camp approaches their "x-risk" problem as if it is a completely novel scenario, and fail to recognize that we already have a rich literature on engineering robust systems. It's basically evolved into a kind of cult (SFBA "rationalism").

posts.text: The LW camp approaches their "x-risk" problem as if it is a completely novel scenario, and fail to recognize that we already have a rich literature on engineering robust systems. It's basically evolved into a kind of cult (SFBA "rationalism").

reply_context.text: the LW community likes to invoke "paperclip maximization" as a kind of parable about x-risk: this is literally just poor objective design and applies to any situation where you define a KPI. Engagement maximization is paperclips. Wealth chasing is paperclip maximization.

posts.text: the LW community likes to invoke "paperclip maximization" as a kind of parable about x-risk: this is literally just poor objective design and applies to any situation where you define a KPI. Engagement maximization is paperclips. Wealth chasing is paperclip maximization.

reply_context.text: Moreover, the kinds of harms are he claims to be concerned about were already an issue via negligent objective design long before AI was a thing. We're already wrestling with self-extinction from ecoloical destruction. Corporations tick all of his x-risk/ASI boxes, but he'd rather tilt at windmills.
